After a while in Spain youâll notice that people tend to use it twice in reply (vale, vale) which is endearing!

3. Hombre

How do you say it? âOmbreâ (the H is silent)

What does it mean and how is it used? It literally means âmanâ, and is also used to affirm or strengthen what youâre saying; typically to mean no, yes/of course, to greet or to plead. Youâll hear:

No â âDo you like your boss?â QuÃ© va, hombre, para nada. (No way, not at all.)

As a bonus, this isnât too strange-sounding to English speakers, because English âmanâ can be used in much the same way.

4. TÃ­o/TÃ­a

What does it mean and how is it used? While these literally mean âuncle,â and âaunt,â theyâre also used informally to generally refer to another person. In the same way English speakers use âdudeâ or âguyâ (âLook at those guys over there!â or âWho said that?â âI donât know, just some dude.â) Spaniards use tÃ­o or tÃ­a. You can also use these words to call the attention of a friend, as in âTÃ­o/tÃ­a, come here!â)

5. Â¿CÃ³mo vas?

How do you say it? âComo basâ (Same thing here â the V is pronounced as a B)

What does it mean and how is it used? Spaniards are a friendly bunch, quick to start up a conversation and armed with several ways to ask the classic âHow are you?â. These greetings are used casually all day â in small talk, such as when meeting friends, with well-known colleagues, chatting with a clerk at the store â so itâs great to know them. Many visitors will quickly learn Â¿QuÃ© tal? and our fifth expression is another to add to your small talk toolbox: Â¿CÃ³mo vas?, literally meaning âHow are you going?â

6. Puente

How do you say it? âPuenteâ

What does it mean and how is it used? Every employeeâs favorite â and a stereotype of life in Spain â is the puente, or three-day weekend. Often due to a saintâs feast day, these âbridgesâ, become the best Mondays and Fridays of the year!

7. Guiri

How do you say it? âGiriâ

What does it mean and how is it used? Anyone wanting to blend in in Spain has done their research on how not to look like a guiri. Guiris, pronounced âgiriâ, are (very obvious) foreigners usually hailing from English-speaking countries or central and northern Europe. The Spanish will call you out as a guiri for being generally non-Spanish: eating dinner or going out for evening drinks far too early; brandishing extra large maps and cameras on city corners; talking really loudly at monuments or while out sightseeing; wearing denim shorts with flip flops year round; and only ordering sangria.

How do you say it? âBuenasâ

What does it mean and how is it used? Start your sunny Spanish morning off with a cheerful Buenos dÃ­as, continue with buenas tardes in the evening and end with buenas noches when itâs time to say goodbye or good night. Or, just stick to the sweet and simple âBuenas!â to say hello at any time of the day. Youâll receive a chipper âBuenas!â in return and can move on to more important considerations â like how much tortilla and patatas bravas are you going to order for lunch?

What does it mean and how is it used? This is another very commonly-used expression in Spain and earns you extra points for stepping outside the usual list of expressions commonly learned by visitors. Â¡Venga ya! (or sometimes simply Â¡Venga!) is a way of expressing surprise or disbelief. Just like âno way,â âcome on!â or âcome off it!â in English, itâs used when you are shocked. (For example, if you learned that your friend had ordered 15 tortillas and ten plates of patatas bravas â then proceeded to eat it all.)
